ChatGPT said:

To display the tasks saved in the database, you'll need to follow three steps in your Electron app:

✅ 1. Define a function in main.js to fetch the tasks

Add this to your main.js where your SQLite db connection and ipcMain are defined:

js
const { ipcMain } = require("electron");

// Fetch all tasks from the database
ipcMain.handle("get-tasks", async () => {
  try {
    const stmt = db.prepare("SELECT * FROM tasks ORDER BY stop_date DESC");
    const tasks = stmt.all(); // Returns an array of rows

    return { success: true, tasks };
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("❌ DB Fetch Error:", err);
    return { success: false, error: err.message };
  }
});

✅ 2. Call the function in renderer.js using ipcRenderer

You’ll need to use ipcRenderer to request the task list from the main process and then render it to the DOM.

js
const { ipcRenderer } = require("electron");

async function loadTasks() {
  try {
    const response = await ipcRenderer.invoke("get-tasks");

    if (response.success) {
      const taskList = document.getElementById("taskList");
      taskList.innerHTML = ""; // Clear previous content

      response.tasks.forEach(task => {
        const taskItem = document.createElement("div");
        taskItem.classList.add("task-item");
        taskItem.innerHTML = `
          <p><strong>${task.name}</strong> (${task.current_date})</p>
          <p>⏱️ Duration: ${task.duration_time}</p>
          <p>💤 Idle: ${task.idle_time}</p>
          <p>Status: ${task.task_status ? "✅ Completed" : "❌ Incomplete"}</p>
          <hr/>
        `;
        taskList.appendChild(taskItem);
      });
    } else {
      console.error("⚠️ Failed to load tasks:", response.error);
    }
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("❌ Renderer Fetch Error:", err);
  }
}

// Optionally call loadTasks() when window loads
window.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", loadTasks);

✅ 3. Add a container to your HTML to display the tasks

html
<!-- Your HTML -->
<div id="taskList" style="margin-top: 20px;"></div>

✅ (Optional) Add a Refresh Button

html
<button id="refreshBtn">🔄 Refresh Tasks</button>

js
document.getElementById("refreshBtn").addEventListener("click", loadTasks);

Let me know if you want to filter tasks by date, status, or show them in a table instead of plain divs.

ChatGPT said:

Thanks for sharing your full task creation and tracking logic. Now that you’re saving completed tasks to the database via:

js
await window.electronAPI.saveTask(taskData);

Let’s complete the setup to display saved tasks from the database when your app loads (or on demand). Here’s how to do it step by step.

✅ 1. Setup in main.js (if not already done)

Make sure this is in your main process (e.g., main.js) to handle fetching tasks:

js
const { ipcMain } = require("electron");

// Get all tasks from SQLite
ipcMain.handle("get-tasks", async () => {
  try {
    const stmt = db.prepare("SELECT * FROM tasks ORDER BY stop_date DESC");
    const tasks = stmt.all(); // all() returns array of all rows
    return { success: true, tasks };
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("❌ DB Fetch Error:", err);
    return { success: false, error: err.message };
  }
});

✅ 2. Expose getTasks via contextBridge in preload.js

Ensure your preload.js has this, assuming you’re using contextBridge:

js
const { contextBridge, ipcRenderer } = require("electron");

contextBridge.exposeInMainWorld("electronAPI", {
  saveTask: (taskData) => ipcRenderer.invoke("save-task", taskData),
  getTasks: () => ipcRenderer.invoke("get-tasks"), // <-- add this
});

✅ 3. Add a Task Display Area to your HTML

Somewhere in your HTML file:

html
<h2>📝 Saved Tasks</h2>
<div id="saved-tasks" class="task-list"></div>
<button id="loadTasksBtn">🔄 Load Saved Tasks</button>

✅ 4. Load and Display Tasks in renderer.js

Now add the following function in your renderer script to fetch and display tasks:

js
async function loadSavedTasks() {
  try {
    const response = await window.electronAPI.getTasks();

    if (response.success) {
      const container = document.getElementById("saved-tasks");
      container.innerHTML = ""; // Clear previous tasks

      response.tasks.forEach(task => {
        const taskDiv = document.createElement("div");
        taskDiv.classList.add("saved-task");

        taskDiv.innerHTML = `
          <p><strong>${task.name}</strong></p>
          <p>📅 ${task.current_date} | ⏱️ ${task.duration_time} | 💤 Idle: ${task.idle_time}</p>
          <p>Start: ${task.start_date} → Stop: ${task.stop_date}</p>
          <p>Status: ${task.task_status ? "✅ Completed" : "❌ Incomplete"}</p>
          <hr/>
        `;

        container.appendChild(taskDiv);
      });
    } else {
      console.error("⚠️ Failed to load tasks:", response.error);
    }
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("❌ Renderer Error:", err);
  }
}

// Load tasks when the button is clicked
document.getElementById("loadTasksBtn").addEventListener("click", loadSavedTasks);

✅ Result

When you click the “🔄 Load Saved Tasks” button, the app will:

  • Retrieve all saved tasks from SQLite

  • Display them in a readable format

  • Show key info like duration, idle time, and status

    We can hook up edit/delete buttons to DB operations too.

ChatGPT said:

Thanks for sharing your entire updated script. You’ve already done most of the heavy lifting, but there are a few improvements and corrections to ensure the saved tasks are displayed consistently with your live tasks and don’t interfere with the current task timer/logic.

✅ Key Fixes & Recommendations

1. ✅ Don’t overwrite active task container

You're replacing all content inside #tasks during loadSavedTasks, which removes any live tasks created by the user before loading. You should display saved tasks in a separate container (e.g., #saved-tasks) to avoid this.

🔧 Fix in HTML:

html
<!-- Add a new section just for saved tasks -->
<h2>📝 Saved Tasks</h2>
<div id="saved-tasks" class="task-list"></div>
<button id="loadTasksBtn">🔄 Load Saved Tasks</button>

2. ✅ Fix loadSavedTasks() to render into the correct container

Update the function to use #saved-tasks instead of #tasks:

js
async function loadSavedTasks() {
  try {
    const response = await window.electronAPI.getTasks();

    if (response.success) {
      const container = document.getElementById("saved-tasks");
      container.innerHTML = ""; // Clear previous saved tasks

      response.tasks.forEach((task) => {
        const taskDiv = document.createElement("div");
        taskDiv.classList.add("saved-task");

        taskDiv.innerHTML = `
          <p><strong>${task.name}</strong></p>
          <p>📅 ${task.current_date} | ⏱️ ${task.duration_time} | 💤 Idle: ${task.idle_time}</p>
          <p>Start: ${task.start_date} → Stop: ${task.stop_date}</p>
          <p>Status: ${task.task_status ? "✅ Completed" : "❌ Incomplete"}</p>
          <hr/>
        `;

        container.appendChild(taskDiv);
      });
    } else {
      console.error("⚠️ Failed to load tasks:", response.error);
    }
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("❌ Renderer Error:", err);
  }
}

3. ✅ Optional Styling (for visibility)

Add to your CSS (or inline if needed):

css
.saved-task {
  background-color: #f5f5f5;
  padding: 10px;
  margin-bottom: 10px;
  border-radius: 6px;
  border: 1px solid #ddd;
}

4. ✅ Optional: Add Auto-load for Saved Tasks

If you want saved tasks to appear only when the user clicks "Load Saved Tasks", keep as-is.

If you want them to auto-load alongside DOMContent, move this to the end of your JS:

js
window.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", () => {
  loadSavedTasks();
});

ChatGPT said:

Got it — you want saved tasks and live tasks to appear in the same container (#tasks). To do this without breaking your live task logic, you just need to:

✅ Modify loadSavedTasks() to reuse createTaskElement()

You already have a powerful createTaskElement(taskText) function that builds your interactive task UI (with timer, date, buttons, etc.).

Let’s reuse that for rendering saved tasks — but with modifications:

  • Set correct start_date, stop_date

  • Set duration/idle values

  • Mark the task as completed

✅ Step-by-step Implementation

1. Update createTaskElement() to accept a full task object

Update the function signature like this:

js
function createTaskElement(taskInput = "A new task", savedData = null) {

Then, inside the function, apply this logic:

js
const taskText = typeof taskInput === "string" ? taskInput : taskInput.name;
const fullDate = new Date().toLocaleDateString("en-US", {
  weekday: "long",
  year: "numeric",
  month: "long",
  day: "numeric",
});

Update date inputs:

js
const startDateInput = dateContainer.querySelector(".start-date");
const stopDateInput = dateContainer.querySelector(".stop-date");

const today = new Date().toISOString().split("T")[0];

startDateInput.value = savedData?.start_date || today;
stopDateInput.value = savedData?.stop_date || today;

Set timer display (below task.innerHTML block):

js
if (savedData) {
  timeDisplay.textContent = savedData.duration_time;
  taskInputEl.value = savedData.name;
  taskInputEl.readOnly = true;
  taskInputEl.style.textDecoration = savedData.task_status ? "line-through" : "none";
}

2. Update loadSavedTasks() to call createTaskElement(task, task)

js
async function loadSavedTasks() {
  try {
    const response = await window.electronAPI.getTasks();

    if (response.success) {
      const container = document.getElementById("tasks");

      response.tasks.forEach((task) => {
        const taskEl = createTaskElement(task, task);
        container.appendChild(taskEl);
      });

ChatGPT said:

You're on the right track with restoring the saved data into the UI, but the reason your task buttons (Start, Pause, Stop, Done, etc.) are not showing is likely because:

You're injecting only partial task data into the DOM, without running the full createTaskElement() logic that builds the entire structure (including buttons).

✅ Solution: Always use createTaskElement() to build tasks

Instead of manually selecting and filling fields after creating a bare wrapper, you should pass the savedData.name to createTaskElement() and let it return a fully structured task. Then, update the other values (time, status, dates) after creation.

✅ Updated loadSavedTasks() Sample

js
async function loadSavedTasks() {
  try {
    const savedTasks = await window.electronAPI.getAllTasks();

    if (!Array.isArray(savedTasks)) return;

    savedTasks.forEach((savedData) => {
      const newTaskEl = createTaskElement(savedData.name); // full DOM with buttons

      // Now safely modify internal elements
      const taskInputEl = newTaskEl.querySelector(".task-text");
      const timeDisplay = newTaskEl.querySelector(".time");
      const startDateInput = newTaskEl.querySelector(".start-date");
      const stopDateInput = newTaskEl.querySelector(".stop-date");

      if (taskInputEl) {
        taskInputEl.readOnly = true;
        taskInputEl.style.textDecoration = savedData.task_status
          ? "line-through"
          : "none";
      }

      if (timeDisplay) {
        timeDisplay.textContent = savedData.duration_time;
      }

      if (startDateInput && stopDateInput) {
        startDateInput.value = savedData.start_date;
        stopDateInput.value = savedData.stop_date;
      }

      document.getElementById("tasks").appendChild(newTaskEl);
    });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("❌ Renderer Error:", error);
  }
}

Thanks for the clarification! You're almost there. The issue you're describing boils down to two things:

✅ Problem 1: Time display not showing on saved tasks

You're calling this inside createTaskElement():

However, duration_time might be null, undefined, or "" in your saved task, depending on what your database returns. You should safely fall back to "00:00:00" if it's missing.

Update this section inside createTaskElement():

js

✅ Problem 2: Saved start/stop dates not showing in <input type="date" />

This is a common issue when the saved values aren't in the correct format that <input type="date"> expects.

🔍 HTML Date Inputs require format:

text
YYYY-MM-DD (e.g. 2025-08-07)

If your saved values include time (e.g. 2025-08-07T00:00:00.000Z), then you must format them.

✅ Fix:

Add a small formatter for dates:

js
function formatDateForInput(dateStr) {
  const d = new Date(dateStr);
  return d.toISOString().split("T")[0]; // returns "YYYY-MM-DD"
}

Then use it in createTaskElement():

js
if (startDateInput && stopDateInput) {
  if (savedData.start_date) {
    startDateInput.value = formatDateForInput(savedData.start_date);
  }

  if (savedData.stop_date) {
    stopDateInput.value = formatDateForInput(savedData.stop_date);
  }
}

🧠 Final Tip

To avoid overriding the saved dates with today's date, make this part conditional too:

js
if (!savedData) {
  const today = new Date().toISOString().split("T")[0];
  dateContainer.querySelector(".start-date").value = today;
  dateContainer.querySelector(".stop-date").value = today;
}

  2. Use it before assigning values to the date inputs.

You said:
Failed to load tasks: no such column: id
ChatGPT said:

The error no such column: id means that your database query is trying to select or order by a column named id, but that column doesn't exist in your tasks table.

✅ Step-by-Step Fix

🔍 1. Check Your Table Schema

Run this SQLite query in your dev tools or SQLite browser to inspect the table structure:

sql
PRAGMA table_info(tasks);

Look at the output — you should see columns like:

cidnametype
0nameTEXT
1current_dateTEXT
2start_dateTEXT
3stop_dateTEXT
4duration_timeTEXT
5idle_timeTEXT
6task_statusBOOLEAN

If id is missing, that’s the cause of the error.

🛠️ 2. Fix Options

✅ Option 1: Add id column

The best fix is to add an id column to your tasks table as a primary key:

sql
ALTER TABLE tasks ADD COLUMN id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT;

⚠️ Note: SQLite doesn’t allow ALTER TABLE to add a column as PRIMARY KEY after the table is created. So if your table doesn’t already have a primary key, you may need to recreate the table:

sql
-- 1. Rename old table
ALTER TABLE tasks RENAME TO tasks_old;

-- 2. Create new table with id
CREATE TABLE tasks (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
  name TEXT,
  current_date TEXT,
  start_date TEXT,
  stop_date TEXT,
  duration_time TEXT,
  idle_time TEXT,
  task_status BOOLEAN
);

-- 3. Copy data
INSERT INTO tasks (name, current_date, start_date, stop_date, duration_time, idle_time, task_status)
SELECT name, current_date, start_date, stop_date, duration_time, idle_time, task_status FROM tasks_old;

-- 4. Drop old table
DROP TABLE tasks_old;

🔁 Option 2: Remove ORDER BY id

If you don’t care about ordering and just want it to work for now, you can remove or change this line in your backend:

js
const stmt = db.prepare("SELECT * FROM tasks ORDER BY id DESC");

Change it to:

js
const stmt = db.prepare("SELECT * FROM tasks"); // no ordering

or order by a column that actually exists, e.g.:

js
const stmt = db.prepare("SELECT * FROM tasks ORDER BY start_date DESC");

✅ 3. Confirm

Once the fix is done:

  • Restart your Electron app

  • Watch your terminal: console.log("📦 Retrieved tasks from DB:", tasks);

  • You should now see saved duration_time values and tasks loading properly

Great question!

To run SQLite queries like PRAGMA table_info(tasks) or check your data during Electron app development, you can’t use browser DevTools because SQLite runs in the Node.js (main) process, not the renderer (frontend).

✅ Here's how you can run SQL queries during development:

✅ Option 1: Log data from Electron's main process

If you're using better-sqlite3 (or similar), locate your main.js or database.js file where the DB is initialized, then:

➕ Add this temporary snippet to log your schema and data:

js
// Show table columns
const pragma = db.prepare("PRAGMA table_info(tasks);").all();
console.log("📋 Table columns:", pragma);

// Show saved data
const tasks = db.prepare("SELECT * FROM tasks;").all();
console.log("📦 All tasks:", tasks);

Run your Electron app (npm start or electron .) and check the terminal/console — you’ll see the output there.

✅ Option 2: Use an external SQLite client

If you'd like to inspect the database manually, use a GUI tool:

💻 GUI Options:

  • DB Browser for SQLite

  • SQLite Viewer Chrome Extension

  • VS Code extension: SQLite Viewer

🧭 Locate your DB file

Find where you’re saving your .db file in the Electron app. For example:

js
const db = new Database(path.join(app.getPath("userData"), "tasks.db"));

This typically resolves to a path like:

php-template
/Users/<your-name>/Library/Application Support/<app-name>/tasks.db (Mac)
C:\Users\<your-name>\AppData\Roaming\<app-name>\tasks.db (Windows)

Then open that file in your SQLite viewer and run:

sql
PRAGMA table_info(tasks);
SELECT * FROM tasks;

In renderer:

💡 Most apps use an auto-incrementing INTEGER PRIMARY KEY:

sql
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS tasks (

  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  current_date TEXT,
  start_date TEXT,
  stop_date TEXT,
  duration_time TEXT,

);

js

sql
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS tasks;

CREATE TABLE tasks (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  current_date TEXT,
  start_date TEXT,
  stop_date TEXT,
  duration_time TEXT,
  idle_time TEXT,
  task_status BOOLEAN
);

To fetch task_id from the SQLite database to the renderer process in your Electron app, you'll need to:

✅ Step 1: Add a Method in main.js (Main Process)

Use ipcMain.handle() to respond to a fetch request:

js
const { ipcMain } = require("electron");

// Fetch all tasks with IDs
ipcMain.handle("get-all-tasks", async () => {
  try {
    const stmt = db.prepare("SELECT * FROM tasks"); // includes task_id if it exists
    const rows = stmt.all();
    return { success: true, tasks: rows };
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("❌ Error fetching tasks:", error);
    return { success: false, error: error.message };
  }
});

✅ Replace "task_id" with "id" if your table uses id as the primary key.

✅ Step 2: Expose it in preload.js

Make it accessible to the renderer:

js
const { contextBridge, ipcRenderer } = require("electron");

contextBridge.exposeInMainWorld("electronAPI", {
  getAllTasks: () => ipcRenderer.invoke("get-all-tasks"),
});

✅ Step 3: Call it from the Renderer

Call it in your frontend code and log the task_id:

js
async function fetchTasks() {
  const result = await window.electronAPI.getAllTasks();
  
  if (result.success) {
    result.tasks.forEach((task) => {
      console.log("📝 Task ID:", task.id); // or task.task_id depending on DB schema
      console.log("Task:", task);
      const taskElement = createTaskElement(task.name, task);
      document.querySelector(".task-container").appendChild(taskElement);
    });
  } else {
    console.error("❌ Failed to fetch tasks:", result.error);
  }
}

fetchTasks();

CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS tasks (

You said:
if (savedData && savedData.task_id) { wrapper.setAttribute("task_id", savedData.task_id); }
ChatGPT said:

Your current code:

js
if (savedData && savedData.task_id) {
    wrapper.setAttribute("task_id", savedData.task_id);
}

is almost correct, but there's a small issue:

👉 setAttribute("task_id", ...) is not standard HTML attribute naming and might not be picked up easily using getAttribute.

✅ Recommended Fix:

Use data-task-id instead. HTML data-* attributes are the proper way to store custom data on DOM elements.

js
if (savedData && savedData.task_id) {
    wrapper.setAttribute("data-task-id", savedData.task_id);
}

Then, you can retrieve it later like this:

js
const taskId = wrapper.getAttribute("data-task-id");

Or using dataset:

js
const taskId = wrapper.dataset.taskId;

🧠 Why this matters:

  • data-task-id is valid HTML.

  • You can style with CSS using data-* attributes.

  • It’s accessible using element.dataset.taskId.

You said:
how do I show id if its auto increment
ChatGPT said:

If task_id is set to auto-increment in your SQLite database, you can retrieve and use it right after inserting a task. Here’s how to do that in both main process (Node) and renderer process (frontend):

✅ 1. Main Process: Insert and Return Auto-Incremented ID

In your main.js or wherever you're handling the DB:

js
ipcMain.handle("save-task", (event, taskData) => {
  try {
    const stmt = db.prepare(`
      INSERT INTO tasks (name, current_date, start_date, stop_date, duration_time, idle_time, task_status)
      VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?)
    `);
    const result = stmt.run(
      taskData.name,
      taskData.current_date,
      taskData.start_date,
      taskData.stop_date,
      taskData.duration_time,
      taskData.idle_time,
      taskData.task_status ? 1 : 0
    );

    return { success: true, task_id: result.lastInsertRowid }; // 👈 Return auto-incremented ID
  } catch (error) {
    return { success: false, error: error.message };
  }
});

✅ 2. Renderer Process: Save and Receive task_id

When saving a task from your frontend (renderer):

js
const taskToSave = {
  name: "Study",
  current_date: "2025-08-07",
  start_date: "2025-08-07",
  stop_date: "2025-08-07",
  duration_time: "00:00:00",
  idle_time: "00:00:00",
  task_status: false
};

const result = await window.electronAPI.saveTask(taskToSave);

if (result.success) {
  const savedTaskId = result.task_id; // 👈 This is the auto-incremented ID from DB
  wrapper.setAttribute("data-task-id", savedTaskId); // Store it on DOM element
}

✅ 3. Optional Debug: Show ID in UI

You can also optionally display the task ID in the DOM:

js
const idDisplay = document.createElement("div");
idDisplay.textContent = `Task ID: ${savedTaskId}`;
wrapper.appendChild(idDisplay);

You said:
show id full saved task in terminal with id
ChatGPT said:

To show the full saved task including its task_id in the terminal after inserting it into your SQLite database (using better-sqlite3), you need to:

  1. Insert the task and get the auto-incremented task_id

  2. Immediately fetch the full row using that task_id

  3. Print it using console.log

✅ Example in main.js (Electron Main Process)

js
ipcMain.handle("save-task", (event, taskData) => {
  try {
    // Insert the new task
    const insertStmt = db.prepare(`
      INSERT INTO tasks (name, current_date, start_date, stop_date, duration_time, idle_time, task_status)
      VALUES (?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, ?)
    `);

    const result = insertStmt.run(
      taskData.name,
      taskData.current_date,
      taskData.start_date,
      taskData.stop_date,
      taskData.duration_time,
      taskData.idle_time,
      taskData.task_status ? 1 : 0
    );

    const task_id = result.lastInsertRowid;

    // Fetch full saved task from DB
    const selectStmt = db.prepare(`SELECT * FROM tasks WHERE task_id = ?`);
    const savedTask = selectStmt.get(task_id);

    // Log it in terminal
    console.log("✅ Saved Task:", savedTask);

    // Return it to the renderer
    return { success: true, task: savedTask };
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("❌ Error saving task:", error);
    return { success: false, error: error.message };
  }
});

✅ What you’ll see in your terminal

bash
✅ Saved Task: {
  task_id: 12,
  name: 'Study for Quiz',
  current_date: '2025-08-07',
  start_date: '2025-08-07',
  stop_date: '2025-08-07',
  duration_time: '00:00:03',
  idle_time: '00:00:00',
  task_status: 0
}

    wrapperEl.remove();

    console.log("✅ Final task update successful:", result);

    // Update UI (e.g., strike-through)
    taskEl.querySelector(".task-text").style.textDecoration = "line-through";

✅ Main Process: Handle full task update in IPC

Add this in main.js (or wherever you’re handling IPCs):

js
ipcMain.handle("update-full-task", async (_, data) => {
  const {
    task_id,
    name,
    duration_time,
    idle_time,
    start_date,
    stop_date,
    task_status
  } = data;

  try {
    const stmt = db.prepare(`
      UPDATE tasks 
      SET name = ?, duration_time = ?, idle_time = ?, 
          start_date = ?, stop_date = ?, task_status = ? 
      WHERE task_id = ?
    `);
    stmt.run(name, duration_time, idle_time, start_date, stop_date, task_status, task_id);

    return { success: true };
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("❌ DB update error:", err);
    return { success: false, error: err.message };
  }
});

ChatGPT said:

You're almost there — your code successfully adds new tasks above old ones, creates the DOM task, and attempts to save it to the database.

However, there's one issue: you're using await inside a non-async function. In JavaScript, you can only use await inside an async function.

✅ Here's the corrected version:

js
document.getElementById("task-form").addEventListener("submit", async function (e) {
  e.preventDefault();
  const taskInput = document.getElementById("task-input");
  const taskText = taskInput.value.trim();

  if (taskText !== "") {
    // Prepare task data
    const today = new Date().toISOString().split("T")[0];
    const taskData = {
      name: taskText,
      current_date: today,
      start_date: today,
      stop_date: today,
      duration_time: "00:00:00",
      idle_time: "00:00:00",
      task_status: false,
    };

    try {
      // Save to DB
      const result = await window.electronAPI.saveTask(taskData);
      console.log("📝 Task added to DB:", result);

      // Create task element with savedData
      const newTask = createTaskElement(taskText, {
        ...taskData,
        task_id: result.id
      });

      // Prepend to list
      document.getElementById("tasks").prepend(newTask);
      taskInput.value = ""; // Clear input
    } catch (error) {
      console.error("❌ Failed to save new task:", error);
    }
  }
});

✅ Changes made:

  • Made the submit callback async.

  • Moved createTaskElement() after saving to the DB.

  • Passed task_id into savedData to ensure it sets the data-id correctly.

This will:

  • Save the task to DB.

  • Create the task element using the actual DB ID.

  • Prepend the task to the top of the list.

ChatGPT said:

The error you're seeing:

pgsql
❌ Failed to save new task: TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'addEventListener')

Means that somewhere inside attachTaskEventListeners, you are trying to attach an event listener to a DOM element that does not exist — it's null.

🔍 Root Cause

Inside attachTaskEventListeners(task, wrapper), you're likely doing something like:

js
const doneBtn = task.querySelector(".done");
doneBtn.addEventListener("click", () => {
  // ...
});

But doneBtn is null, because task is not the right parent, or the button doesn’t exist in the expected place.

✅ Fix

Before adding addEventListener, check if the element exists. Update your attachTaskEventListeners function like this:

js
function attachTaskEventListeners(task, wrapper) {
  const doneBtn = task.querySelector(".done");
  const editBtn = task.querySelector(".edit");
  const deleteBtn = task.querySelector(".delete");

  if (doneBtn) {
    doneBtn.addEventListener("click", () => {
      console.log("✅ Done clicked!");
      // Update logic here...
    });
  } else {
    console.warn("⚠️ No .done button found");
  }

  if (editBtn) {
    editBtn.addEventListener("click", () => {
      // ...
    });
  }

  if (deleteBtn) {
    deleteBtn.addEventListener("click", async () => {
      const taskId = wrapper.getAttribute("data-id");

      if (taskId) {
        const confirmed = confirm("Are you sure you want to delete this task?");
        if (!confirmed) return;

        const result = await window.electronAPI.deleteTask(Number(taskId));
        if (result.success) {
          wrapper.remove();
        } else {
          console.error("❌ Failed to delete from DB:", result.error);
        }
      } else {
        wrapper.remove();
      }
    });
  }
}

✅ Also double-check:

  • That you're passing task and wrapper correctly into attachTaskEventListeners from createTaskElement.

  • That the .done, .edit, and .delete buttons are present inside your HTML task.innerHTML markup.

Summary

You’re trying to bind events on elements that don’t exist yet. Fix it by:

  1. Verifying selectors and structure.

  2. Adding null checks before using .addEventListener.

ChatGPT said:

Thanks for sharing your full attachTaskEventListeners function. There are two important issues that may be causing errors or incorrect behavior, especially when clicking Done:

✅ Problem 1: Incorrect DOM Query for .start-date and .stop-date

In your doneBtn.addEventListener("click", ...) code block, you have:

js
const startDate = document.querySelector(".start-date").value;
const stopDate = document.querySelector(".stop-date").value;

This uses document.querySelector, which will always return the first matching element in the entire document, not the one inside the specific task.

🔧 Fix:

Use the scoped element references startDateInput and stopDateInput that you already have at the top of the function:

js
const startDate = startDateInput.value;
const stopDate = stopDateInput.value;

This ensures that you're grabbing values for that specific task, not another one.

✅ Problem 2: Saving New Task Instead of Updating Existing One

In your done button handler, you call:

js
await window.electronAPI.saveTask(taskData);

But when a task is marked as done, it should update the existing task in the database — not insert a new one. Otherwise, you'll end up duplicating it.

🔧 Fix:

  1. Retrieve the task_id from the wrapper:

    js
    const taskId = wrapperEl.getAttribute("data-id");

  2. Pass that in the taskData and call an updateTask method:

js
if (!taskId) {
  console.error("❌ Cannot mark done — missing task ID");
  return;
}

const taskData = {
  task_id: Number(taskId),
  name: taskInput.value,
  current_date: new Date().toISOString().split("T")[0],
  start_date: startDateInput.value,
  stop_date: stopDateInput.value,
  duration_time: formatTime(seconds),
  idle_time: formatTime(idleSeconds),
  task_status: true,
};

try {
  const result = await window.electronAPI.updateTask(taskData);
  console.log("📝 Task updated in DB:", result);
} catch (error) {
  console.error("❌ Failed to update task:", error);
}

✅ This assumes you’ve implemented a window.electronAPI.updateTask() function in your Electron preload and backend.

ipcMain.handle("update-task", async (event, taskData) => {
  const {
    task_id,
    name,
    current_date,
    start_date,
    stop_date,
    duration_time,
    idle_time,
    task_status,
  } = taskData;

  try {
    await db.run(
      `UPDATE tasks
       SET name = ?, current_date = ?, start_date = ?, stop_date = ?,
           duration_time = ?, idle_time = ?, task_status = ?
       WHERE task_id = ?`,

    );
    return { success: true };
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("DB Update Failed:", err);
    return { success: false, error: err.message };
  }
});

🧠 Summary

  • Use updateTask() for the "Done" button.

  • Never use saveTask() unless you’re creating a brand new entry.

  • Ensure the task_id is correctly attached to the task element via setAttribute("data-id", result.id) when first inserting it.

Let me know if you’d like to grey out or disable the controls after marking a task as done.

ChatGPT said:

The error you're seeing:

javascript
TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'addEventListener')

means that you're trying to call .addEventListener() on something that is null — i.e., the DOM element doesn’t exist or wasn’t found.

🔍 Where It Happens

js
document.getElementById("confirmDelete").addEventListener("click", async () => {

This line (and the one for "cancelDelete") is inside attachTaskEventListeners, which runs every time a task is created. That means:

  • If those buttons (confirmDelete, cancelDelete) are not in the DOM when this function runs, you’ll get this error.

  • Or, if they are inside a modal that hasn't been rendered or injected into the DOM yet — same issue.

✅ Fixes

✅ Fix 1: Move Modal Button Listeners Outside attachTaskEventListeners

Since confirmDelete and cancelDelete are static global elements, you only need to attach their event listeners once, ideally at the top of your script:

js
// Only once, not inside a function
document.getElementById("confirmDelete").addEventListener("click", async () => {
  if (!currentTaskToDelete) return;

  const taskId = currentTaskToDelete.getAttribute("data-id");

  if (taskId) {
    const result = await window.electronAPI.deleteTask(Number(taskId));
    if (result.success) {
      currentTaskToDelete.remove();
    } else {
      console.error("❌ Failed to delete from DB:", result.error);
    }
  } else {
    currentTaskToDelete.remove();
  }

  currentTaskToDelete = null;
  hideDeleteModal();
});

document.getElementById("cancelDelete").addEventListener("click", () => {
  currentTaskToDelete = null;
  hideDeleteModal();
});

Then in attachTaskEventListeners, just define showDeleteModal() and set currentTaskToDelete:

js
deleteBtn.addEventListener("click", () => {
  currentTaskToDelete = wrapperEl;
  showDeleteModal();
});

function showDeleteModal() {
  document.getElementById("deleteModal").style.display = "flex";
}

function hideDeleteModal() {
  document.getElementById("deleteModal").style.display = "none";
}

✅ Fix 2: Ensure Modal Exists in HTML

Make sure the modal and its buttons exist in the HTML:

html
<div id="deleteModal" style="display: none;">
  <p>Are you sure you want to delete?</p>
  <button id="confirmDelete">Yes</button>
  <button id="cancelDelete">Cancel</button>
</div>

✅ Summary

  • The error comes from trying to access document.getElementById("confirmDelete") before the element exists.

  • Move the delete modal button event listeners outside attachTaskEventListeners() — so they only run once.

  • Make sure the modal is present in your HTML before your script runs.

Let me know if you'd like to refactor the modal with better styling or animation too.

ChatGPT said:

You're getting this error:

javascript
Renderer Error: TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'addEventListener')

This error almost always means: you're trying to call .addEventListener() on an element that doesn’t exist in the DOM.

From the stack trace, the issue seems to come from inside your attachTaskEventListeners() function, which is being called by createTaskElement() after submitting the form.

✅ Root Cause

Some button or element you’re trying to add an event listener to (like pauseBtn, doneBtn, deleteBtn, etc.) is null because it doesn't exist in your HTML or template when createTaskElement() is called.

✅ How to Fix It

✅ Step 1: Add a console.log() in createTaskElement()

Temporarily log the elements you're querying in createTaskElement or attachTaskEventListeners, like this:

js
console.log("⛏ pauseBtn", wrapperEl.querySelector(".pause-btn"));
console.log("⛏ doneBtn", wrapperEl.querySelector(".done-btn"));

You’ll see which one is null.

✅ Step 2: Fix the HTML inside createTaskElement

Make sure your HTML includes all the buttons you’re targeting. Example:

js
function createTaskElement(taskText, savedData = {}) {
  const wrapper = document.createElement("div");
  wrapper.classList.add("task-wrapper");
  wrapper.innerHTML = `
    <input type="text" class="task-input" value="${taskText}" />
    <button class="pause-btn">Pause</button>
    <button class="done-btn">Done</button>
    <button class="delete-btn">Delete</button>
    <span class="timer">00:00:00</span>
    <input type="date" class="start-date" />
    <input type="date" class="stop-date" />
  `;

  if (savedData.task_id) {
    console.log("💾 Setting data-id with task_id:", savedData.task_id);
    wrapper.setAttribute("data-id", savedData.task_id);
  }

  attachTaskEventListeners(wrapper);
  return wrapper;
}

Ensure that .pause-btn, .done-btn, etc. are exactly what your querySelector calls expect.

✅ Step 3: Defensive Checks (Optional but Recommended)

In attachTaskEventListeners():

js
function attachTaskEventListeners(wrapperEl) {
  const pauseBtn = wrapperEl.querySelector(".pause-btn");
  const doneBtn = wrapperEl.querySelector(".done-btn");
  const deleteBtn = wrapperEl.querySelector(".delete-btn");

  if (!pauseBtn || !doneBtn || !deleteBtn) {
    console.warn("❗ One or more task buttons are missing:", {
      pauseBtn,
      doneBtn,
      deleteBtn,
    });
    return; // Stop further execution to avoid crash
  }

  pauseBtn.addEventListener("click", async () => {
    // ...
  });

  doneBtn.addEventListener("click", async () => {
    // ...
  });

  deleteBtn.addEventListener("click", () => {
    // ...
  });
}

✅ Summary

  • The error is because you're calling .addEventListener() on a null element inside attachTaskEventListeners.

  • Log your elements and ensure they are properly rendered in the DOM by createTaskElement().

  • Make sure your .innerHTML contains all the buttons you're trying to add listeners to.

  • Add defensive checks to prevent crashing when elements are missing.
